articles.headline: Auto Parts Suppliers May Get Aid
articles.snippet: The Obama administration announced a $5 billion fund to guarantee payments to suppliers for products shipped to automakers.
articles.abstract: The Obama administration announced a $5 billion fund to guarantee payments to suppliers for products shipped to automakers.
articles.lead_paragraph: DETROIT  The Obama administration signaled its intent Thursday to provide broad relief to the American auto industry with the creation of a $5 billion fund to aid troubled parts suppliers.

articles.headline: House Approves 90% Tax on Bonuses After Bailouts
articles.snippet: Spurred by anger over A.I.G., the House voted 328 to 93 to tax bonuses paid by any company owing more than $5 billion in bailout money.
articles.abstract: Spurred by anger over A.I.G., the House voted 328 to 93 to tax bonuses paid by any company owing more than $5 billion in bailout money.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The House overwhelmingly approved on Thursday a near total tax on bonuses paid this year to employees of the American International Group and other firms that have accepted large amounts of federal bailout funds, rattling Wall Street as lawmakers rushed to respond to populist anger.
articles.byline: By Carl Hulse and David M. Herszenhorn

articles.headline: Fragile Signs of Hope Emerging in the Gloom of Mugabe’s Rule
articles.snippet: Children and teachers have returned to classes, for now, as Western nations debate how to aid Zimbabwe but avoid feeding its president’s patronage machine.
articles.abstract: Children and teachers have returned to classes, for now, as Western nations debate how to aid Zimbabwe but avoid feeding its president’s patronage machine.
articles.lead_paragraph: HARARE, Zimbabwe  On his first day as education minister in a government so broke that most schools were closed and millions of children idle, David Coltart said he got a startling invitation.

articles.headline: The Money Is Gone. Now What?
articles.snippet: Americans’ efforts to place blame for the financial crisis and to try to recoup their losses are distracting them from their new economic reality.
articles.abstract: Americans’ efforts to place blame for the financial crisis and to try to recoup their losses are distracting them from their new economic reality.
articles.lead_paragraph: The losses from the worldwide financial implosion are only now being tallied up. Adjusting to the reality is proving hard.

articles.headline: False Start on a Laser Remedy for Fungus
articles.snippet: A company has begun marketing its laser for use on toenail infections, even though it has not received clearance from the F.D.A.
articles.abstract: A company has begun marketing its laser for use on toenail infections, even though it has not received clearance from the F.D.A.
articles.lead_paragraph: Laser eye surgery has enabled millions of people to throw away their eyeglasses. Now several medical technology companies are hoping that lasers aimed at the feet will allow millions to take their socks off, even in public.

articles.headline: G.E. Makes the Case for Its Finance Unit
articles.snippet: General Electric presented analysts a detailed look inside GE Capital in an attempt to prove that its finance division is better positioned than the competing banks.
articles.abstract: General Electric presented analysts a detailed look inside GE Capital in an attempt to prove that its finance division is better positioned than the competing banks.
articles.lead_paragraph: At 30 Rockefeller Plaza, in the Art Deco theater that is home to “Saturday Night Live,” humor was not part of the program on Thursday. Instead, General Electric executives were doggedly making the case that the company’s huge finance arm is not just a troubled bank in disguise, as investors have feared.

articles.headline: Rapid Declines in Manufacturing Spread Global Anxiety
articles.snippet: The depth and speed of the manufacturing plunge are striking, and recall conditions that led to the Great Depression.
articles.abstract: The depth and speed of the manufacturing plunge are striking, and recall conditions that led to the Great Depression.
articles.lead_paragraph: Since it was founded by his great-grandfather in 1880, Carl Martin Welcker’s company in Cologne, Germany, has mirrored the fortunes of manufacturing, not just in Europe but around the world.
